AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

description: Change of Use of rear of premises from Use Class E(d) (formerly D2) Indoor Sports (Billiards club) to Use Class E(b) (formerly A3) Sale of Food/Restaurant
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Notwithstanding Section 55 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) and the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), the premises shall only be used as a restaurant and for no other purposes whatsoever (including any other purposes falling within Class E of the Schedule to the Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987 (or any provision equivalent to that class in any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification).Reason: The acceptability of the development is highly dependent upon the exact nature of the use of the site and other uses, whether within the same use class or permitted by the General Permitted Development Order, are unlikely to be acceptable in planning terms.

The restaurant to which this permission relates shall not open outside of the following hours:09:00 to 23:00 Monday to Friday10:00 to 23:00 on Saturdays10:00 to 23:00 on Sundays and bank holidaysReason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No fans, louvres, ducts or other external plant other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved shall be installed without the prior written approval of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties and the visual amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.ConsultationOne objection received. The objection is summarised as follows: - Excessive height or bulk of buildings - Inappropriate design/layout - PrivacyAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Other mattersDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Paragraphs 189 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Officer Comment: The proposed build out and enclosure over two storeys of the terrace/balcony of the host property would be at odds with the prevailing character of the host property and adjoining properties in Samuel Gray Gardens. It is considered that the proposal would create an incongruous addition that would not be subordinate or of an architectural style sympathetic to the host property and would be visually intrusive in the views of the building from neighbouring vantage points. It is considered that the proposal would not be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that the proposal would have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the host property and surrounding area and as a result cause less than substantial harm to the non designated heritage the Thames Side Strategic Area of Special Character.It is considered that the proposal would not impact on the setting of the adjacent Riverside North Conservation Area or Metropolitan Open Land. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the loss of light or loss of privacy.However due to the proposals size, siting and design in relation to the neighbouring properties it is likely that the proposal would give rise to actual or perceived overlooking of neighbouring properties and create an unnecessary sense of enclosure to neighbouring properties by way of its overbearing intrusive appearance to the detriment of the existing living conditions of neighbouring occupiers. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be not in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than not in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

The RBK Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer has raised an objection and provided a comment in response to the submitted details below:- Para 3.3 of the submitted CLP states that 'This CLP does not cover the site setup and demolition phase and basement excavation as those phases have taken place on-site. This CLP also excludes the initial foundation works to the electrical intake room undertaken in February 2023 and the subsequent setting out works on site that only require minor vehicle movements on site.' This is not acceptable by RBK Highways. As this is a pre-commencement condition this statement suggests that a start has already been made on site and significant amounts of work carried out. In addition to this officers from RBK Highways visited the site on 29th November and it was observed that there were plant machinery and building materials on site as well as accommodation caravans suggesting that works were being undertaken.- The document does not contain sufficient information as required by the condition.- The dates mentioned in the construction programme do not seem to correlate with dates mentioned in other parts of the same document.- The tracking shows vehicles entering and exiting the site. However, they also show that the traffic island in the middle of the road would need to be taken out for these maneuvers to work as prescribed. The applicant has already been advised that the rearrangement of Park Terrace will involve works carried out with an agreement under  Section 278 of the Highways Act 1980, so until that is completed they do not have any authorisation to carry out any work on any part of the highway. With the above comments, Highways would not support the discharge of condition 5 of application 19/00330/FUL.

The RBK Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer has raised an objection and provided a comment in response to the submitted details below:- Para 1.12 of the submitted CMP states that 'The CLP (RPS Reference: JNY11750-01 CLP), outlines that the site setup and demolition, and the basement excavation and piling phases have already been undertaken on-site together with the foundation works for the electrical intake room undertaken in February 2023.' This is not acceptable by RBK Highways. As this is a pre-commencement condition this statement suggests that a start has already been made on site and significant amounts of work carried out. In addition to this officers from RBK Highways visited the site on 29th November and it was observed that there were plant machinery and building materials on site as well as accommodation caravans suggesting that works were being undertaken.- The document does not contain sufficient information as required by the condition.- The tracking shows vehicles entering and exiting the site. However, they also show that the traffic island in the middle of the road would need to be taken out for these maneuvers to work as prescribed. The applicant has already been advised that the rearrangement of Park Terrace will involve works carried out with an agreement under  Section 278 of the Highways Act 1980, so until that is completed they do not have any authorisation to carry out any work on any part of the highway.With the above comments, Highways would not support the discharge of condition 6 of application 19/00330/FUL.

PLEASE READ CAREFULLY: On the 1st May 2024 the Council adopted a new Householder Local List. Please ensure that your application submission includes all the necessary documentation as required by the new Local List and complete and submit a "Householder Checklist - Section 3" to confirm that you have provided all mandatory documents.The new Householder Local List and Checklist can be obtained via the council's website: https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applicationsThe LPA will not conduct any validation checks until the correct Checklist has been submitted. Upon receipt of a completed Checklist, the application will be assigned to a Validation Officer to review. Please do not simply state N/A anywhere in the checklist without a written justification. If you need to make any changes to your application please try to do this via the Planning Portal website where possible. If that is not possible please send amended documents via the email address quoted in this letter.

Please confirm the proposal to be discussed at the Pre-application meeting. The Pre-application form states "Basement extension to provide one office space, bedroom and bathroom", but the submitted plans show that a new dwelling is being proposed to the rear of 71 Windsor Avenue.The fee paid (£174) is for a meeting for a Household extension.Please confirm if you wish to discuss a proposal for a new dwelling, and if so you must pay the fee:Remote meeting only: £1500Written Advice only: £1500Remote meeting and written advice: £2130

PLEASE READ CAREFULLY: On the 1st May 2024 the Council adopted a new Householder Local List. Please ensure that your application submission includes all the necessary documentation as required by the new Local List and complete and submit a "Householder Checklist - Section 3" to confirm that you have provided all mandatory documents.The new Householder Local List and Checklist can be obtained via the council's website: https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applicationsThe LPA will not conduct any validation checks until the correct Checklist has been submitted. Upon receipt of a completed Checklist, the application will be assigned to a Validation Officer to review. Please do not simply state N/A anywhere in the checklist without a written justification. If you need to make any changes to your application please try to do this via the Planning Portal website where possible. If that is not possible please send amended documents via the email address quoted in this letter.

You should provide as much information about your project as possible. The more detail you can provide about your proposal, the more accurate and useful our advice will be.As a minimum, please provide a location plan that shows the site address with the site boundary highlighted.
